content.question: On the interval <math alttext="negative 3 less than x, less than 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></math>, the first derivative of the function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f prime of x equals, the fraction with numerator x squared minus 4, and denominator open parenthesis, x plus 3, close parenthesis, squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, and the second derivative of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="f double prime of x equals, the fraction with numerator 6 x plus 8, and denominator open parenthesis, x plus 3, close parenthesis, cubed, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>. On which of the following intervals is the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> concave down?

choices.label: <math alttext="negative 3 less than x, less than negative four thirds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></math>

<math alttext="negative four thirds less than x, less than 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></math>

<math alttext="negative 3 less than x, less than negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></math> and <math alttext="2 less than x, less than 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></math>
<math alttext="negative 2 less than x, less than 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="negative 3 less than x, less than negative four thirds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></math>

topic.text: 5.6: Determining Concavity of Functions over Their Domains
